The hint is in the name, solinaceous plants, the nightshade family include potatoes and tomatoes and, I believe, the red, green and yellow peppers too (same peppers just stages of maturity).

This is cool, especially the last part. I breathe at a lower rate, because I have a persistent fetal hemoglobin allele, which is more efficient than the ordinary adult alpha version. 1/9th of my hemoglobin is fetal, 4/9ths is half alpha, half gamma, and the other 4/9ths is double alpha (ordinary adult version). Genetic analysis is so cool.

I really like Hank but after this vid, I think I love Katherine. The next time someone suggests I'm wrong at work, I am ABSOLUTELY going to say, 'You have something on your face there' in a dismissive manner.

The bat bombs were likely based on an old story of a clever man who with his army was setting siege to a city. The people of the city wanted to negotiate, and he said that he would be satisfied with a token tribute: One pigeon from each family. In those days pigeons were kept for eggs and meat by most people. Upon receiving the pigeons, he waited until evening and attached small containers with live coals to each one, and released them. The pigeons, of course, all flew home to their cotes, many of which then caught fire, and the city burned. We still have a proverb that the pigeons have come home to roost. [NOT Chickens, but pigeons}

I always get a little too angry whenever these videos come out and half the comments are people talking about the term nonbinary being "unscientific". Maybe because it hits a little too close to home, there's no worse condemnation for me than calling something I accept irrational and not based on empirical evidence or logic. When I was a kid I wanted to be a biologist, and now I'm going to university I am studying mathematics because I just can't accept things that are inelegant or have questionable validity. I also used to be a person who thought like those people in the comments, and I lost a friend because of it. It wasn't even ideas that made me so insensitive, it was words. I hadn't really been taught the gender and biological sex were different things, and for a very brief time after I was I wasn't convinced English didn't need redundancies in its words for biological sex. People aren't denying the existence of sexual dimorphism (forgetting for a time rarer occurrences that lead to intersex peoples who shouldn't really be forgotten), what they are saying is that small hormonal differences and the production of one kind of genitals or another is not necessary or sufficient to act in a permutation one of two almost entirely socially and historically defined roles (or for that matter to be committed to and defined by those genitals). The entire notion that having more complex ways to describe things is less scientific is alien to me, especially in the softer "stamp collecting" fields. Yes, making models is great, but biology is too messy to even make biological sex binary, it's crazy to think you can have a completely accurate nontrivial binary classifier for something as complex in its structure as a brain. Yes, the brain is lacking in a lot of ways I want my primary computer to be, it falls into local maxima or minima for games where there is an ideal solution, and it can be clouded by emotions evolutionarily designed for primitive circumstances, but it's still a network with around 86 billion nodes and it's the biggest computational black box problem...ever. It seems like you're losing information if you decide there are only two types of this abstract structure, wrong if you're basing it on another loosely correlated factor outside the structure, and losing the battle if you assign a bunch of cultural and historical baggage to people who don't want it.
